results.title: Circulation and the human body. -- Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: Uses animation to explain the needs of the body’s cells and how some of these needs are serviced by the circulation system. It details how blood returns from the capillaries to the heart through the venous system, and how the chambers of the heart pump the blood through the pulmonary circulation, then back through the arterial system to the capillaries.

results.brief_description: Demonstrates the structure and function of the human circulatory system, and analyses the work of the heart, arteries, and veins. Photography by Frank Bundy.

results.title: Circular saws
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Woodworking machinery series”.
The film starts with a short description of a saw bench and stresses the point that saws must be kept sharp. Machine sharpening is demonstrated, followed by hand sharpening and setting. Special types of saws, inserted tooth saw, swage saw and novelty tooth saw, are described. After sharpening, the rip saw is replaced on its spindle and packing inserted. Safety precautions saw guard, riving knife and push stick, are shown. A cross-cut saw is demonstrated. Adjustment for angle cutting, use of trenching heads for cutting housings.

results.title: Circular and squint bays, gable knees, corbelling, tile creasing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
Shows various methods of bricklaying including the trammel method for circular walls; templet method; obtuse angled wall, use of squint bricks, purpose made and hand cut; knee of oversailing brickwork; angle cuts for gable bricks; corbels for wall plate; corbelling for attached pier; tile creasing with brick-on-edge finish.

results.title: Circling the globe in comfort
results.creator_credit: Jaaf Nieuwenhuis and Royal Rotterdam Lloyd
results.brief_description: Historical documentary of a round-the-world trip by the 23,000 ton Dutch liner, the “Willem Ruys”, beginning from Sydney and calling into Wellington (NZ), Lima (Peru), Balboa (Panama City), Miami, Bermuda, Southampton, Rotterdam, passing Portugal, Gibraltar and Malta to Port Said and into the Suez Canal. From the Suez Canal the voyage then continues on through the Red Sea to aden, into the Indian Ocean to Colombo, then Singapore, across the Equator past Java and Christmas Island to Cape Leeuwin and finally arriving in Melbourne.

From the Suez Canal the voyage then continues on through the Red Sea to aden, into the Indian Ocean to Colombo, then Singapore, across the Equator past Java and Christmas Island to Cape Leeuwin and finally arriving in Melbourne.

results.title: Circles of learning
results.creator_credit: Patricia Roy, David W. Johnson, Roger Johnson and University of Minnesota
results.brief_description: Provides an introduction to co-operative learning strategies in the primary and postprimary school. Shows an across-the-curriculum approach that develops the co-operative learning skills children need to work in small groups. Though set in the US context, it has applicability to the local classroom situation. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level students.

results.title: Circles II
results.creator_credit: Doris Chase, King Screen Productions and Perspective Films
results.brief_description: Members of the Mary Stanton Dance Ensemble perform in and around huge fibreglass circles designed by artist/filmmaker Doris Chase. A superimposition technique is used on the circles and human forms, which rotate in a of different patterns and colors. The dancers move with, around and through the kinetic sculptures. Music by George Kleinsinger. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Circle of the sun = Le Soleil perdu
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: At the 1961 gathering of the Blood Indians of Alberta the exciting spectacle of the Sun Dance was captured on film for the first time. The film also reflects the predicament of the young generation, those who relinquished their ties with their own people but have not yet found a firm place in a changing world. (Awards include: London, Brussels, Toronto)
